text: To:
label: BODY

text: Transportation Committee
label: BODY

text: Date: August 13, 2008
label: BODY

text: From: Bob Dean, Principal Regional Planner
label: BODY

text: Re:
label: BODY

text: Scenario Construction
label: BODY

text: A central piece of the GO TO 2040 planning process is the evaluation of alternative future
label: BODY

text: scenarios.  Scenarios are combinations of actions (policies, strategies, and investments) that
label: BODY

text: represent alternative paths that the region could take toward reaching its desired future, as
label: BODY

text: expressed in the Regional Vision.  The purpose of the scenario evaluation process is not to
label: BODY

text: select one single scenario that will be adopted in its entirety.  Instead, it is meant to allow us
label: BODY

text: to examine different potential paths that the region could take toward the realization of its
label: BODY

text: vision.  Ultimately, the most effective pieces from each one of the scenarios will be chosen
label: BODY

text: and combined into a preferred scenario.
label: BODY

text: Below are draft recommendations from staff concerning the identities of the alternative
label: BODY

text: future scenarios that will be under consideration.  Please note that these descriptions focus
label: BODY

text: primarily on the transportation aspects of each scenario; each will also have detailed
label: BODY

text: environmental, economic, housing, land use, and other components.
label: BODY

text: Scenario 1: This will be a reference scenario, describing what will happen if we
label: BODY

text: continue on our current path.  This is mostly produced for the purposes of
label: BODY

text: comparison.  It will demonstrate that our current trends will lead to an undesirable
label: BODY

text: future, and that action and change is needed.
label: BODY

text: Scenario 2: This scenario will focus on preserving those aspects of the region that we
label: BODY

text: value most, including open space, affordable housing, historic buildings, etc.  In the
label: BODY

text: transportation area, this scenario will include measures that preserve the function of
label: BODY

text: our transportation system without requiring major infrastructure investment.  It will
label: BODY

text: have non-capital intensive features like improved pedestrian and bicycle facilities,
label: BODY

text: car-sharing, transit operating improvements, transportation demand management
label: BODY

text: (TDM) techniques, and access management along arterials, for example.  Although
label: BODY

text: this scenario does not have extensive investment in physical improvements, it will
label: BODY

text: invest more heavily in education, workforce development, and similar actions.
label: BODY

text: 233 South Wacker Drive
label: BODY

text: Suite 800, Sears Tower
label: BODY

text: Chicago, IL 60606
label: BODY

text: www.cmap.illinois.gov
label: BODY

text: Scenario 3: This scenario will reinvest heavily in our existing communities and
label: BODY

text: infrastructure.  “Existing communities” are defined here as those areas where
label: BODY

text: development already exists.  Transportation investments will be sizable, and will
label: BODY

text: primarily include reconstruction or expansion of existing infrastructure, both transit
label: BODY

text: and road (as well as other non-transportation infrastructure).  This focuses our
label: BODY

text: infrastructure investments on existing communities, trying to use existing assets as
label: BODY

text: much as possible.  Improvements to the region’s freight infrastructure will be an
label: BODY

text: explicit part of this scenario.  Land use patterns will follow infrastructure
label: BODY

text: investments, leading to development that is transit-oriented and mixed-use.
label: BODY

text: Scenario 4: This scenario will focus on innovation, in terms of new technologies or
label: BODY

text: policy solutions, to reach our vision.  In the area of transportation, it will feature
label: BODY

text: extensive use of Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS) solutions, variable pricing,
label: BODY

text: alternative energy and fuels, and facility design that takes advantage of the latest (or
label: BODY

text: anticipated) technologies; non-technological innovations such as context sensitivity
label: BODY

text: are also part of this scenario.  Improved communications capabilities may also
label: BODY

text: reduce demand on the transportation system overall.  Transportation facilities that
label: BODY

text: support innovative development nearby are also included in this scenario.  This is
label: BODY

text: expected to feature the development of currently undeveloped land, but the negative
label: BODY

text: impacts of this development are minimized through innovative solutions like
label: BODY

text: conservation design techniques.
label: BODY

text: The alternative scenarios will not include specific major capital projects, but will instead
label: BODY

text: focus on systematic improvements that can be made to the transportation system.  The
label: BODY

text: proposed approach for addressing major capital projects will be brought to the
label: BODY

text: Transportation committee for discussion at the September meeting.
label: BODY

text: More information on the options that were examined in determining this scenario
label: BODY

text: construction framework is included in the attached document.
label: BODY

text: ACTION REQUESTED: Discussion.
label: BODY

text: Scenario construction process
label: BODY

text: Description of thematic scenarios
label: BODY

text: At working committee meetings in June 2008, staff presented several options for the
label: BODY

text: construction of alternative scenarios.  There was general agreement that we construct our
label: BODY

text: scenarios using a thematic method.  In thematic scenario construction, each scenario is a
label: BODY

text: combination of individual strategies, or a course of action.  The strategies can be grouped
label: BODY

text: into thematic scenarios by any method desired; the process for this proposed for CMAP will
label: BODY

text: be described later.
label: BODY

text: The purpose of the scenario evaluation process is not to select one single scenario that will be
label: BODY

text: adopted in its entirety.  Instead, it is meant to allow us to examine different potential paths
label: BODY

text: that the region could take toward the realization of its vision.  Ultimately, the most effective
label: BODY

text: pieces from each one of the scenarios will be chosen and combined into a preferred scenario.
label: BODY

text: A thematic organization was chosen after examining various other possible methods for
label: BODY

text: scenario construction, including:
label: BODY

text: Varying scenarios by intensity, as in the Envision Utah process.  In this construction
label: BODY

text: method, one scenario includes no good planning, one includes lots of good planning,
label: BODY

text: and the others vary between these bookends.  This model is useful for establishing
label: BODY

text: that there is support for planning in general, but it does not help very much in
label: BODY

text: prioritizing actions.  Therefore, this is more useful for organizations that are trying to
label: BODY

text: create broad support for planning, something that CMAP assumes already exists in
label: BODY

text: this region.  However, this method still may have value in terms of communication
label: BODY

text: with the general public.
label: BODY

text: Maximizing one goal over another.  For example, an environmental scenario could be
label: BODY

text: created which focuses on achieving our environmental goals, and this could be tested
label: BODY

text: against an economic or an equity-focused scenario.  While this method is fairly
label: BODY

text: simple and easy to explain, it also leads to false choices (environmental actions can
label: BODY

text: also be economically beneficial, for example), and it would pit groups of stakeholders
label: BODY

text: against each other unproductively.
label: BODY

text: Focus on investment in different areas.  This method assumes that many of our
label: BODY

text: region’s resources are committed to maintaining our infrastructure, education, health
label: BODY

text: care, and other systems, but that there is a certain amount of discretionary funding.
label: BODY

text: Scenarios constructed using this method would focus the investment of this
label: BODY

text: discretionary funding on infrastructure versus education, for example.  While this is
label: BODY

text: an interesting public policy question (how best can the public sector use its
label: BODY

text: resources), it leads to the same unrealistic tradeoffs described above.  Additionally,
label: BODY

text: the focus on public sector investment ignores the role of private sector investment or
label: BODY

text: other public sector actions such as regulation.
label: BODY

text: Assigning growth to one area or another.  This method would forecast population
label: BODY

text: and jobs for different geographies and then adjust these forecasts to determine the
label: BODY

text: effect of faster population growth in Kane County, for example.  This method is
label: BODY

text: undesirable given the consensus-based nature of CMAP’s decision-making.  Also, it
label: BODY

text: is unrealistic, because neither CMAP nor any other group has the ability to simply
label: BODY

text: shift jobs and people between jurisdictions.  While it may lead to interesting results
label: BODY

text: concerning the effects of growth in one area or another, it does not lead to a
label: BODY

text: prioritization of strategies.
label: BODY

text: Within thematic scenario construction, there are a variety of ways to assign strategies to
label: BODY

text: different scenarios.  It is proposed that CMAP involve its stakeholders and committees in
label: BODY

text: this process, as described later in this document.
label: BODY

text: Key standards met through use of thematic scenarios
label: BODY

text: Before the decision that thematic scenario construction was the right method, a number of
label: BODY

text: baseline scenario features were established to guide the choice of the best scenario
label: BODY

text: construction method.  These included the following:
label: BODY

text: Scenarios should be logical and internally consistent, and should also be reasonable
label: BODY

text: views of the future, rather than “straw men” which exist to be destroyed.  Thematic
label: BODY

text: scenarios can provide more realistic futures than the other methods, which tend
label: BODY

text: toward extremes.
label: BODY

text: The purpose of scenarios is to prioritize actions for implementation.  Because
label: BODY

text: thematic scenarios are combinations of actions, they can do this.  (So could several
label: BODY

text: other of the scenario construction methods, as well.)
label: BODY

text: In comparison to the reference scenario, each scenario should lead to an overall
label: BODY

text: improvement in environmental quality, economic competitiveness, equity, and other
label: BODY

text: vision themes.  Thematic scenarios can be constructed in a way to ensure that each
label: BODY

text: contains strategies to improve the environment, economy, etc.  Other scenario
label: BODY

text: options, such as the maximizing of one goal over another, would tend to be less
label: BODY

text: balanced, and in some cases, it would be difficult to ensure that this standard were
label: BODY

text: met (for example, an economically-focused scenario could easily have a negative
label: BODY

text: effect on the environment.)
label: BODY

text: Minimum standards or “floors” should be included in each scenario for basic
label: BODY

text: maintenance of the system, continued funding for education, an acceptable level of
label: BODY

text: planning for safety and security, etc.  This could actually be accomplished through
label: BODY

text: any of the scenario construction methods.
label: BODY

text: Cost constraints should be clear.  This can either be accomplished through holding
label: BODY

text: costs equal and ensuring that all scenarios cost the same, or by explicitly stating the
label: BODY

text: tradeoffs between benefits and costs (such as higher taxes).  Because thematic
label: BODY

text: scenarios are combinations of explicit strategies, either of these methods can work
label: BODY

text: with a thematic scenario construction method.
label: BODY

text: Scenarios should be treated as examples that illustrate potential futures, not the full
label: BODY

text: range of futures that are available to the region.  This is a key consideration in
label: BODY

text: thematic scenarios, and one way in which they may be more difficult to use than
label: BODY

text: other options.  They will appear to have a degree of arbitrariness to anyone not
label: BODY

text: involved in their construction.  For example, it is easy to understand that an
label: BODY

text: “environment vs economy vs equity” tradeoff is done to provoke thought and
label: BODY

text: discussion.  Because the choices involved in thematic scenarios are not so simplistic,
label: BODY

text: and the future they describe are more realistic, they may be viewed by some as actual
label: BODY

text: choices rather than illustrations.
label: BODY

text: Scenarios should be designed with public communication in mind.  This will be a
label: BODY

text: greater challenge for thematic scenarios than for others.  However, it is more
label: BODY

text: important to select a scenario construction process that allows the most robust
label: BODY

text: analysis possible.  Given sufficient effort and creativity, even the most complex
label: BODY

text: processes can be communicated to the public.
label: BODY

text: In addition to these standards established ahead of time, a number of issues were discussed
label: BODY

text: at the working committee meetings which can be accommodated within thematic scenario
label: BODY

text: construction.  A key issue was the responsiveness of scenarios to outside forces, such as
label: BODY

text: energy prices, overall global economic conditions, and climate change.  This can be
label: BODY

text: addressed by doing “robustness testing” after scenarios are constructed.  For each scenario,
label: BODY

text: we can ask how much sense that particular combination of actions would make in a future
label: BODY

text: with considerably higher energy prices, for example.  Energy usage is likely to be calculated
label: BODY

text: for each scenario, so it would be a simple matter to identify the most and least energy-
label: BODY

text: efficient scenarios.  This may not matter for decision-making now; we need to select a
label: BODY

text: preferred set of actions based on the best information that we currently have.  But as we get
label: BODY

text: a clearer picture of the future of energy prices, we can re-prioritize our strategies based on
label: BODY

text: our changing expectations.
label: BODY

text: Another critical issue was the place of Chicago within the global economy, as it is clear that
label: BODY

text: global trends do affect the region.  There are a variety of actions that can be take in response
label: BODY

text: to this, ranging from increased local food production, to specializing in green architecture, to
label: BODY

text: centralizing our position as an international freight hub, to trying to save our manufacturing
label: BODY

text: jobs, etc.  Which one of these courses of action makes most sense depends largely on one’s
label: BODY

text: future expectations.  However, regardless of this, the plan needs to directly address our
label: BODY

text: place within the global economy.
label: BODY

text: Request for comments
label: BODY

text: CMAP staff have developed some potential courses of action, included as a separate
label: BODY

text: attachment, that could be included as components of alternative scenarios.  These are meant
label: BODY

text: as a starting point for discussion.  Please recall when reviewing these that a preferred
label: BODY

text: scenario will likely contain elements from each of these – the purpose of the scenarios is to
label: BODY

text: examine different alternatives and spark discussion about our priorities for actions and
label: BODY

text: investments.
label: BODY
